### Description

### Reproduction

### Additional Information

* Fresco version: 2.0.0
* animated-gif: 2.0.0
* Platform version: any device
author: ilyamuromets

comments.body: Hey there, it looks like there has been no activity on this issue recently. Has the issue been fixed, or does it still require the community's attention? This issue may be closed if no further activity occurs. You may also label this issue as "bug" or "enhancement" and I will leave it open. Thank you for your contributions.
Closing this issue after a prolonged period of inactivity. If this issue is still present in the latest release, please feel free to reopen with up-to-date information.
The problem still exist!
Hey! How can we reproduce the issue? Can you give us some sample code? Rounding for GIFs is currently not supported.

Oh, that explains the issue.
When you include animated-gif, we'll use the animated GIF decoder for the image, which does not support rounding. For a single frame GIF, the system can decode a static image (which is happening when you don't have animated-gif).

The solution to this problem is to supply this method:

```java
ImageDecodeOptions options = ImageDecodeOptions.newBuilder().setForceStaticImage(true).build();
// Pass the options to the Drawee view via a DraweeController
draweeControllerBuilder.setImageRequest(
          ImageRequestBuilder.newBuilderWithSource(uri)
              .setImageDecodeOptions(options)
              .build());
```
@oprisnik thanks, it's working.

title: Handle gifs in RecyclerView
author: gold24park

comments.body:
If you have many high resolution GIF images, then it's somewhat expected to see these kind of performance problems. It's simply due to the fact that one is burning through a lot of Bitmap objects very quickly.

If those images are controlled by you, then one solution would be to resize them server side which should improve the playback performance. Another solution is to just animate a subsection of those images.

You can try to increase the Bitmap memory cache to allow more caching which could help in some cases.

There are obviously parts of the image pipeline that make the assumption that a URL will always point to the same resource.

title: prefetchToBitmapCache not support post process?
body:
``` java
Fresco.getImagePipeline().prefetchToBitmapCache(
        ImageRequestBuilder.newBuilderWithSource(Uri.parse(url))
                .setPostprocessor(new XXXPostprocessor())
                .build(),
        null);
```

XXXPostprocessor.process() not executed. 
Changing `prefetchToBitmapCache` to `fetchDecodedImage`, XXXPostprocessor.process() will be excuted!
author: fengshenzhu

comments.body:
You're right. `prefetchToBitmapCache()` only takes the image as far up the pipeline as the main bitmap cache.

Post-processing and caching the result of that comes later.

Pre-fetching before you need the image will give you the benefit of downloading the image and decoding into bitmap cache. Then calling `fetchDecodedImage()` will take the image from cache and run the post-processor.

title: Stored in the cache
body:
Hi :D !
I want to know the duration of cache storage fresco.
Memorycache and Diskcache

How much for a long time a store?
author: YoonKyoungTae

comments.body:
## Diskcache

> com.facebook.cache.disk.DiskStorageCache#FUTURE_TIMESTAMP_THRESHOLD_MS
> FUTURE_TIMESTAMP_THRESHOLD_MS = TimeUnit.HOURS.toMillis(2);
>   /**
> - If any file timestamp is in the future (beyond now + FUTURE_TIMESTAMP_THRESHOLD_MS), we will
> - set its effective timestamp to 0 (the beginning of unix time), thus sending it to the head of
> - the queue for eviction (entries with the lowest timestamps are evicted first). This is a
> - safety check in case we get files that are written with a future timestamp.
> - We are adding a small delta (this constant) to account for network time changes, timezone
> - changes, etc.
>   */

## Memorycache

> com.facebook.imagepipeline.cache.CountingMemoryCache
> com.facebook.imagepipeline.cache.CountingLruMap

## My Point Of View

The store durtion of Both Memorycache and Diskcache depend on calling submit new image request.

Memorycache is evicted by LRU eviction strategy.
Diskcache is evicted by Comparing cache's timestamp to FUTURE_TIMESTAMP_THRESHOLD_MS  .

If you don't submit new image request, not update the cache , and the  cahe has always existed.

Thanks @huangjunkun for your thorough answer. I'll close this issue as I think that answers it.

I'll add that both memory and disk cache employ LRU eviction. The future timestamp check in disk cache is additional to cover scenarios where the device time changes and cached items now appear to have been cached in the future. These could otherwise be retained indefinitely while more recent items are evicted.

Using Fresco can I detect whether an image has come from a redirected URL? 

eg, I request www.example.com/images/a_cat.jpg and it returns (through redirect) www.example.com/images/no_such_image.jpg

author: snoopgroggygrog

comments.body: There is not API for that. Can you share more details about your use case ? What do you want to do ? Prevent redirections ? Collect some stats ?

In my particular case, I want to know know when a redirection has taken place so I can replace the image (from the redirected URL) with a different one. 

A more general case might be that when images from URLs A, B, and C are all loaded from a redirected URL D, they are all cached separately, even though they came from the same source (D). 

At the very least, being able to grab the original URL and the actual URL (the one that the network connection was redirected to), when an image loads would be useful for a variety of cases.
This is a useful idea but not something we are currently prioritising internally. If you'd like to send a pull request, that would be brilliant.
